newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian stocks follow bonds to higher end.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian stocks follow bonds to higher end.

text.p: The Australian share market finished on a strong note on Wednesday, closing at its day's highs as the bond market climbed off the floor after Tuesday's solid selloff.

At 4.30 p.m. (0630 GMT), the All Ordinaries index was 13.9 points higher at 2258.5 while September share price index futures were up 26 points at 2,263 and at a 4.5 point premium to the underlying index.
Brokers said the Dow's rebound off its day's lows, after the U.S. bond market was rescued by weaker than expected economic data, had proved sufficient incentive for local players.
"We have taken a guide from New York," said dealer Peter Struk of brokerage Reynolds and Co, noting that reasonable buying had underpinned the day's strength.
"There has been good buying and we have held our ground."
Other traders made similar sentiments, saying the Dow's recuperative powers had allowed the local market to gain ground.
"It's been a pleasing showing," said a Sydney broker.
"With the Dow showing some resilience, bonds have given us the impetus to go ahead," he said.
Caution was evident from both traders, though, as they pointed to continuing concerns over U.S. interest rates.
"It is still very much wait and see. People are still jittery about the U.S.," Struk noted.
Banks stole the limelight, the big banks rebounding as bond markets recovered.
The banking index outperformed the rest of the market, adding 1.67 percent on the day compared to the benchmark All Ordinaries' gain of just 0.62 percent.

Other strong performances came from Kerry Packer-controlled television and magazine group, Publishing and Broadcasting, which scored highly with investors after a 50 percent higher full year net profit of A$225.4 milion.
Among others, Qantas Airways shares ended off a couple of cents as oil prices jumped in response to the Iraqi crisis.
Other results came from transport and logistics group TNT which saw its shares end firmer, despite a sharply lower A$9.84 million full year net profit.
Caterers and providores Spotless Services and Spotless Group both saw their shares close firmer after reporting higher year net profits of A$20.27 million and A$18.05 million respectively.
Insurance group HIH Winterthur ended only just firmer despite a sharp increase in full year net profit to A$26.1 million.
Kitchen and bathroom fittings manufacturer GWA International closed higher despite posting a flat full year net profit of A$30.12 million.

Oil and gas major Woodside saw its shares close stronger after nearly doubling its first half net profit to A$84.38 million, while coal miner QCT Resources also ended higher after more than doubling its full year net profit to A$71.47 million.
Dairy group QUF's full year net profit of A$11.51 million was down as were its shares by the close.
Rises outnumbered falls by a ratio of about nine to seven, while about 32 percent of stocks traded remained steady.
In other local markets, bonds rallied sharply after Tuesday's aggressive sell-off as the market regrouped and shrugged off the absence of any Reserve Bank rates announcement.
By 4.35 p.m. (0635 GMT), 10 year T-bonds were yielding 8.19, down 0.11 on Tuesday's levels.
The Australian dollar inched ahead Wednesday after the Reserve Bank held official rates steady in the wake of Tuesday's policy meeting.
By 5.00 pm (0700 GMT) the dollar had made hard work of a modest gain to be quoted at US$0.7922/27 from an early US$0.7914/19 and US$0.7913/18 here late on Tuesday.
FUTURES/OPTIONS - Futures trading saw moderate activity as did options markets although both were slowed from Tuesday's strong levels.
Total options traded 44,477 (58,477)
Turnover in September SPI contracts totalled 6,605 (11,217)
Short-term range Support Restnce RSI-14 MA-10 MA-20
Banks impresss as bond market bounces back.
Media shares surge with strong profit result.
*Spotless Services A$2.17 (+.07) 2.14/2.17 Vol: 3,000
Caterers/providores shares edge up after full year profits.
Transport group reported lower year net profit of A$9.84 million.
Insurance group reported half year net profit of A$26.1 million.
Coal producer's year net profit rose 142 pct to A$71.47 million
Resources leaders close firmer as Dow, bonds bounce.
-- Walter Watson 61-2 9373 1800
